awd_titl_txt: EPRI: Spray-Freezing of Phase-Change Materials for Decoupled Condensation and Heat Rejection in Next Generation Air-Cooled Power Plants
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed transformative "dry-cooling" technologies completely eliminating the use of water for cooling steam condensers in modern electric power plants. This is achieved using air-cooled spray-freezing of phase-change materials (PCM).This project has leveraged the spray-freezing of phase-change materials (PCMs) to decouple steam condensation and heat rejection in the development of novel air-cooled condensers. In the system, heat is transferred from the condenser steam to a slurry bath comprised of solid PCM particles suspended in liquefied PCM. The liquid PCM is then drawn from the bath and sprayed into a cooling tower, where the heat is rejected to the ambient air. The PCM droplets solidify as they are convectively cooled and fall back to the PCM slurry bath completing the cycle. The integrated university-industry team has developed novel PCMs with high thermal conductivity and optimal spray/jetting characteristics, investigated spray freezing system designs, and built lab-scale sub-systems to characterize the proof-of-concept design. Results from this project have been disseminated through two archival journal articles, one referred conference publication, as well as numerous conference presentations and invited seminars. Two Ph.D. dissertations have been completed and two senior design teams have been mentored. New collaborations with Advanced Cooling Technologies and Worley Parsons have been established.
